Award.AwardTitle: Descriptive Set Theory And Polish Groups at the Bernoulli Center
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for US based researchers to attend conferences and workshops, which will take place as part of the thematic program on Descriptive Set Theory and Polish Groups at the Bernoulli Center at the École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL) in Lausanne, Switzerland from January 1 until June 30, 2018.

Descriptive set theory is classically defined as the study of definable sets in Polish spaces - those topological spaces which are separable and completely metrizable. The subject has long thrived in its connections with classical areas of mathematics such as harmonic and functional analysis and logic. Over the course of the last 25 years, however, a vast number of new interactions have opened up the field to novel and exciting directions. The semester long program will organize a number of activities in and around modern aspects of descriptive set theory and its links with other areas of mathematics. An important focus is to facilitate research on the structure of Polish topological groups, which recently has gathered momentum partially due to work in descriptive set theory. The website for the program can be found here:

https://bernoulli.epfl.ch/semesters/32/show

POR.DRECONTENT:
The thematic semester Descriptive set theory and Polish groups took place at the Bernoulli Center from January 1st to June 30th, 2018. Descriptive set theory is a branch of set theory which concerns regular subsets of separable complete metric spaces (Polish spaces). Especially since the 1980s and 1990s, the subject has focused heavily on interactions with other fields such as ergodic theory, Banach space geometry, operator theory, and probability.

Funding for the semester was provided by the Bernoulli Center, while the NSF provided additional funding for travel and lodging costs of US based participants. The NSF support allowed us to cover the expenses of 18 US based visitors participating in the program for a week or more each. Most of these participants were graduate students or post-docs without other NSF support. Therefore their participation was greatly facilitated by the funds provided for this purpose.

The goal of the program was to bring together several separate groups of researchers who each have interests overlapping descriptive set theory.
Because of the difficulty of supporting a large group of long term visitors, this was primarily done through five one-week workshops and conferences.
In the case of each event, we aimed to include a mixture of those outside of descriptive set theory (a little less than half of the speakers) as well as experts in descriptive set theory. The program also featured 3 distinguished Bernoulli lectures given by Stephen Jackson (University of North Texas),
Mikhail Gromov (Institut des Hautes Etudes Scientifiques and New York University), and Slawomir Solecki (Cornell University).

The first conference of the semester was on Borel combinatorics and ergodic theory and took place 5--9 February, 2018.This was organized by Clinton Conley and Damien Gaboriau and featured 15 speakers and 37 participants.
Stephen Jackson presented his Bernoulli Lecture during this meeting. The focus of this workshop was mainly  interactions between descriptive set theory and  ergodic theory.

The second  conference concerned the Structure and dynamics of Polish groups and took place 19--23 March, 2018. It was organized by Andreas Thom and Todor Tsankov and featured 21 speakers, 44 participants. As the title of the conference suggests, the talks split into two broad categories: dynamics (Ackerman, Evans, Glasner, Matte Bon, Zucker) and the structure of Polish groups (Ben Yaacov, Kwiatkowska, Malicki, Melleray, Monod). There were also three talks concerning applications of ultraproducts and model-theoretic ideas to dynamics by Ando, Carderi, and Ibarlucia.

During 26--29 March, 2018 there was a workshop on the Large scale geometry of Polish groups organized by Justin Moore and Christian Rosendal. The workshop featured 16 speakers and 46 participants with an engaging Bernoulli lecture What is probability given by Mikhail Gromov. The workshop brought together several distinct groups of researchers. There were talks concerning Banach space geometry (Gilles Lancien, Valentin Ferenczi),  analytical aspects of groups (Francois Le Maitre, Piotr Nowak, Phillip Wesolek), geometric group
theory (e.g. Goulnara Arzhantseva, Cornelia Drutu, Alain Valette), topology (Alexander Dranishnikov), and the large scale geometry of transformation groups (Michael Cohen, Emmanuel Militon).

The second workshop concerned Ideals and exceptional sets in Polish spaces. It was organized by Marton Elekes and Slawomir Solecki and took place
4--8 June, 2018. It featured 16 speakers and 35 participants. There were several talks about definable ideals on Polish spaces (Kubis, Saran, Todorcevic) as well as two talks about definability of maximal families (Brendle, Tornquist). The talks by Darji and Matheron were about ideals related to dynamical systems. Raghavan reported on a joint work with Todorcevic in which they proved a conjecture of Galvin in infinite Ramsey theory.

The capstone meeting of the semester was a general conference
on Descriptive set theory organized by Alexander Kechris, Benjamin Miller, and Stevo Todorcevic. It took place 18--22 June, 2018 and featured 19 speakers and 60 participants. Slawomir Solecki gave a Bernoulli lecture on applications of Fraisse methods in topology as part of the meeting. This was a general conference bringing together researchers from all branches of Descriptive Set Theory. There were talks in Borel combinatorics and countable Borel equivalence relations (Conley, Gaboriau, Gao) and the theory of projective sets (Friedman, Kanovei). Another important topic was the Borel complexity of both sets and equivalence relations (Andretta, Marcone, Motto Ros, Nies, Pequignot).
